(a)    Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are in force and include; Emergency Response Plan SH-014 and Environmental Management Plan MSP-023.

(b)    Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals, Inc. (Jayhawk operates a batch specialty chemical manufacturing facility near Galena, Kansas.  The industrial area within which JayhawkA?s property and manufacturing operations are located is known locally as the Jayhawk Plant, dating back to its creation in the 1940s. That portion of the Jayhawk Plant Site containing JayhawkA?s property, buildings and equipment will be referred to hereinafter as the "Facility". 
    The Facility is located on approximately 850 acres of a 2,200-acre industrial     complex. JayhawkA?s Unit 1 encompasses approximately 29 acres and Unit 2     encompasses approximately 25 acres. The Facility is located approximately 3.5          miles north of the junction of Kansas Route 66 and U.S. Highway 400 at     Riverton, Kansas. 

    The regulated substances handled at Jayhawk include:
1.    Acetaldehyde  CAS # 75-07-0
2.    Ammonia (water solution) 24% CAS # 7664-41-7
3.    Chlorine CAS # 7782-50-5
4.    Hydrogen Chloride CAS # 7647-01-0
5.    Isopropyl Chloroformate CAS # 108-23-6
6.    Methyl Chloroformate CAS # 79-22-01
7.    Anhydrous Ammonia CAS # 7664-41-7
8.    Methyl Chloride CAS # 74-87-3
    
(c)    Jayhawk ensures accident prevention through the development and maintenance of process safety information, performing process hazard analyses on covered systems and a program to address any deficiencies noted during the reviews, writing and maintaining current operating procedures with operator participation, training employees with appropriate knowledge to safely perform their jobs, ensuring equipment functionality with a thorough mechanical integrity program, reviewing and documenting all changes affecting covered processes and training employees to the changes prior to start-up, performing pre-startup safety reviews, completing compliance audits at least e

very three years, investigate incidents within 48 hours of the incident and involve employees and/or contractors, following the site written employee participation plan, utilizing the site work permit policy that includes hot work permitting, complying with the site policy for contractor safety, and through training and following the site emergency response plan intended to protect human health and the environment.

Worst case scenarios were developed for each regulated chemical. The assumptions made included that the chemical was instantaneously released through catastrophic failure of the container, and if there were multiple containers of a single chemical within the same proximity, the release included the entire contents of all of the containers.

    Wind Speed:     1.5 meters/second (3.4 miles/hour)
    Stability Class:     F

Worst case scenarios were developed for each regulated chemical. The assumptions made included that the chemical was instantaneously released through catastrophic failure of the container, and if there were multiple containers of a single chemical within the same proximity, the release included the entire contents of all of the containers.

Acetaldehyde
JayhawkA?s facility includes a tank that contains 108,000 pounds of acetaldehyde when full. It is used as a primary raw material in the production of one of the finished products in Unit 1. Acetaldehyde stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. According to US EPAA?s RMP*Comp A?  (RMPComp), that quantity of acetaldehyde results in a 0.3-mile radius to the one pound per square inch (p.s.i.) overpressure endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modelin

g results for the worst case scenario for acetaldehyde:
Category:     Flammable Gas
Liquefied     Under pressure
Quantity Released:     108,000 pounds
Release Type:     Vapor Cloud Explosion
Estimated Distance to 1 psi overpressure:     0.3 miles
The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 3.6-mile radius of the acetaldehyde tank (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 3517 residential persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.

Anhydrous Ammonia
A worse case scenario for anhydrous ammonia is the catastrophic failure of the storage tank.  Since the tank contains 96,000 pounds when full, the scenario involves the release of 96,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia through 3-inch hole.  Anhydrous ammonia stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. According to RMPComp, that quantity of anhydrous ammonia results in a 3.6-mile radius to the 0.14 mg/L toxicity endpoint.  The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worse case scenario for anhydrous ammonia:
Category:    Toxic Gas
Liquefied     Under pressure
Release Duration:     10 minutes
Release Type:     
Storage Parameters:     Release from tank
Hole or puncture area:     6.5square inches
Release Rate:     9600 pounds per min
Mitigation Measures:     NONE
Estimated Distance to 1 psi overpressure:    3.6 miles
The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 3.6-mile radius of the anhydrous ammonia. The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 3517 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.

Alternate Scenarios
The catastrophic failure of the containers, or simultaneous failure of all containers for a chemical, is highly unlikely. The tanks and cylinders have safety devices and systems to prevent or minimize the effect of any accidental release. An alternative scenario has been selected for each chemical that, although still very unlikely to occur, has a higher probability of occurrence than the worst case scenario, in accordance with U.S. EPA guidance.
For all alternative scenarios, the following assumptions were made:
Wind Speed:    3 meters/second (6.7 miles/hour)
Stability Class:    D
Air Temperature:    77 degrees F (25 degrees C)
Residential population, public receptors and environmental receptors

were assessed for each chemical within the radius of its associated endpoint. In most there was residential population, no environmental receptors, and the only public receptor that appears in the available data is the Boston Mills School located one-half mile east. This school was investigated and no longer exists. Therefore, there are no public receptors within the maximum endpoint radius of the alternative case scenarios.

Acetaldehyde
A more likely scenario for acetaldehyde is the failure of the railcar unloading system. The chemical is transferred to the tank using nitrogen pressure and a closed loop system, and should a hose fail, the entire contents of the tank might escape. The alternative scenario for acetaldehyde is the failure of a 2-inch unloading line releasing all of the contents of a tank. Since the tank contains 108,000 pounds when full, the alternative scenario involves the release of 108,000 pounds of acetaldehyde through a 2-inch hose. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:
Category:    Flammable Gas
Liquefied     Under pressure
Release Duration:     19.7 minutes
Release Type:     Vapor Cloud Explosion
Storage Parameters:     Release from Pipe
Hole or puncture area:     6.5 square inches
Release Rate:     5480 pounds per min
Mitigation Measures:     NONE
Estimated Distance to 1 psi overpressure:    0.07 miles
The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.07-mile radius of the acetaldehyde tank (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.

Jayhawk utilizes the LOPA (layer of protection analysis) for process hazard analysis of each covered process.  This detailed analysis guides the site in determining specific prevention measures to preclude accidents.

(d)    Jayhawk operates a modern facility with state of the art safety policies, practices and systems. There have been no off-site consequences involving regulated processes, or regulated chemicals, at the facility. There is no five-year accident history involving either regulated processes or chemicals that involve personnel injury, death or significant property damage.

(e)    The facility has an Emergency Response Plan intended to protect human health and the environment. There is a procedure for the notification of local emergency response agencies and the public. Training is provided to all employees on the Emergency Response Plan and the emergency equipment available at the facility. This Emergency Response Plan is updated as often as necessary, but not less than once every three years.  Emergency response is provided by the Galena, KS Fire Department with mutual aid assistance agreements with Columbus, and Baxter Springs, KS Fire Departments. Columbus is located approximately 10 miles northwest of the facility, and Baxter Springs is located approximately 10 miles southwest of the facility. There is a Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) for Cherokee County, KS. Mutual aid response times are approximately 30 minutes from the initiation of the notice. There is a Jayhawk staffed Emergency Response Team which has training in incipient stage fire response. Additional support is provided through coordination of the emergency with outside agencies through use of the plant telephone and emergency notific

ation system.

(f)    Apart from compliance with specific guidelines, the policy of Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals is also aligned to continuous development, especially in terms of plant and occupational safety, environmental protection, protecting the health of its employees, product safety, transportation safety and site security.  Specifically, EJFC operates with a policy of investigating near misses and incidents and includes findings into updates of our safety management policies and procedures.  Communication to plant personnel is routinely held to inform and train employees on improvements learned from the incident reporting management system.
